review_title: Not as good as I thought
pros: A lot of nice colleagues who initially felt proud to be part of the Dartmouth community. Many hardworking people. Some departments are much better than others. Good benefits package.
cons: Not listing my work area as it's niche, but there is a fair amount of toxic management. Bad behavior by management is swept under the rug. Salaries were not fair for the workload. Very little diversity. They like to talk about diversity, but there is some kind of disconnect there. It starts feeling more like just talking the talk. The area is beautiful, but the housing market is awful. Not much to do up there unless you like to ski. People talk about living in the "Dartmouth Bubble". After awhile, I understood what that meant. I also realized that it was clear who was on the inside and outside of that "bubble".

review_title: Okay if you only want a paycheck
pros: Lots of wonderful colleagues who genuinely want to do good work, make improvements, and push Dartmouth forward.
cons:
Leadership is non-existent. 
Organization is reactive, not proactive.
Staff are not respected or considered in any decisions.
Blatant discrimination as evidenced by old practices, outdated systems, and archaic policies - all when brought to the attention of leadership swept under the rug with the decision to "settle" lawsuits, claims, or investigations instead of rectifying issue.
Smoke & mirrors - will obscure and embellish the truth to hide what is really happening "behind the scenes" such as their staff compensation program which is unethical and creates inequities across the institution (STAFF SHOULD CONSIDER UNIONIZING)
No strategic vision or plan for the College so every division/dept runs around working in silo reacting to whatever crisis is happening in that moment, and typically without the resources they need to handle it, as Dartmouth likes to pretend they are broke as well.
Nothing is measured therefore there is no accountability on anyone for anything ever, which I suppose could be a good thing if you just want to collect a paycheck!

review_title: Okay experience, but I do not recommend
pros: Naturally beautiful area. Met some very nice people.
cons: No diversity. If you're not a student or don't have an MD or PHd, you are basically NOTHING here. You will not advance and you cannot work your way up. There is a very elitist attitude towards administrative and operational staff. They won't pay you well and they won't even appreciate you. As an operations manager I was reduced to taking notes in meetings and all my ideas were ignored. It was extremely hierarchical. I thought, as a place of learning, Dartmouth would be open minded, but I've met more down to earth leaders in the corporate world. I never again want to work in Higher Education. I know have a job at a Healthcare tech company and I have advanced more in 1 year than i did in the 3 I spent at Dartmouth.

pros: Benefits, union, and pay...that’s it.
cons: Slowly eats your soul. The management is terrible and the fellow employees are manipulative/backstabbing. There is not one professional supervisor in FOM. The whole department is a joke among custodians. Don’t talk to anyone, and stay away from management and you’ll be fine. If drugs or drinking on the job bother you, don’t apply. If you are able to remove your brain from your head for 8 hours, you might be able to make it. If you can stand a gossipy environment where you are constantly having to defend yourself; this could be your new place of employment. The war between first shift and third shift seems like a joke...it’s not. When you choose a first or third shift position, you are really picking the Sharks is the Jets. It’s like walking straight into West Side Story. The pay, benefits, and personal time are amazing. But, is it worth your sanity? Your peace of mind? Three years was enough for me. I thought I found a dream job, but I just stepped into one of the biggest facades the upper valley has to offer.

pros: Excellent learning experience- professors are excited about helping you work on real projects.

pros:
Dartmouth is an exceptional place where to work. I am an international, working at Dartmouth as faculty. The people you meet at Dartmouth are generally outstanding in their profession, passionate about their work and about contributing to the institution. As this is important for them, they will help you integrating with the workplace and being in a position of being effective in your work: the common goal is to make Dartmouth a better place than it already is.

I have been at Dartmouth for over 5 years, and all the people I have met are happy to work for this renown employer. Regarding myself, I am glad I had the opportunity of working there, and it has been a life changing adventure.
cons:
Dartmouth is located in a rather isolated geographical position. While this carries some big advantages, including short commuting times, and access to incredible natural resources - summer and winter time - this has to be your cup of tea. It took me more than two years to understand how to enjoy myself in this new environment - that is: spending time being active in the outdoors. On a positive side Dartmouth provides high level cultural entertainment through the Hopkins Center (top notch theatrical performances, movies), and Boston and NY are connected by direct buses operated by Dartmouth. However, don't count too much on this option: if you are there for work, it is likely you will be busy  a good number of weekends
 per year ! :-)  A few hours spent in the outdoors in the back of your house is a more likely scenario, than taking off for Boston or NY for the full week-end.

review_title: One of the better campus jobs
pros: Opportunity to help create or be involved in events and activities around campus
cons: Some responsibilities seem unrelated to the House Center (ex: work that UGAs should be doing for the residence halls)

pros: Good benefits, good networking, good work/life balance
cons: Low pay, inequality of pay amongst administrative staff.

pros: Dartmouth College is situated in an idyllic valley environment- it is so beautiful and there are so many outdoor activities to pursue year-round. It is part of this physical landscape that makes Dartmouth such a special place to work and grow due to the type of people that are attracted to the area. You constantly run into fellow co-workers due to the small geographic location, so bonds are strong. It really feels like everyone has a vested interest in helping their co-workers. I feel that all employees are valued and treated fairly, and the benefits package is one of the best I've ever seen. Dartmouth also attracts world-class talent to their concert venue, inspiring leaders for speeches and talks, and amazing artisans to the area.
cons: Although it can also be a positive (see above!), the smaller area and surrounding community is probably also one of the biggest drawbacks. You can be sure that you'll see a fellow employee wherever you go (and consequently have to be on your best behavior- which makes it tough to be a young person looking to let loose). If you're an in-betweener (aka- recent grad) you may have a harder time transitioning from college life to "real life" and experience a strange sense of connection and detachment from the College (which I imagine would be true of any recent grad working at a University- be it their alma mater or not). I think this feeling was amplified by the fact that I did not graduate from Dartmouth, but I digress...

review_title: A great place to work for undergrads
job_title: IT Student Worker in Hanover, NH
pros:
The IT&C department at Dartmouth might just be one of campus' best-hidden undergrad employers. They have a variety of jobs in roles ranging from IT consulting to telephone support to working with information technology to responding to classroom IT needs.

The hourly pay began at $11/hr when I started (which was competitive at the time) and you received a $0.25/hr raise for every term you worked there. 

Best of all, the skills and information you learn there are applicable to a wide variety of fields. I was able to land my management consulting job thanks mostly to my experiences at IT&C!
cons: The starting hourly pay of $11/hr was no longer competitive with other on-campus jobs at the end of my 4 years at Dartmouth. Also, it would be nice if ambitious students could take on more responsibility over time. I began to feel that I was "outgrowing" the role by year 3, but stayed due to the high hourly pay, work environment, and skills that I could put on my resume.

review_title: Too many managers, wasteful spending in Administrative Computing Dept.
pros: Slow paced environment, not much expected of employees in the computing services dept, so the job is basically extremely easy. Attend a few meetings, write good notes, nod your head, and look busy, and they'll think you're a superstar. Great for people with low ambition who want to make more than they'll ever make on the open market or private industry.
cons: Management in technical services believes that although they are severely over-manned, hiring outside consultants to do the heavy lifting is the way to cement your reputation as the "get-it-done" manager. Very, very political environment with practically 2 managers to every direct report. Complete inertia, lots of hesitation to try new things - the direct opposite of what John Kemeny wanted Dartmouth to be back in the 60's and 70's - and a reliance on outdated technologies and name brand services rather than any faith in university-friendly open source solutions that are simpler and cost less. Absolutely no diversity among the employee base - almost everyone is white. Lots of useless titles, e.g. Director of this, Senior Director of that, most that add up to no responsibilities at all.

job_title: Epidemiologic Research Analyst in Hanover, NH
pros: Engaging work at the DAC.  Loved Medicare data and claims research.  Engaging PI's, 95% of them top notch researchers, full of ideas and strong workmanship.  We published and worked hard on projects together in a colloquial, fast-paced, results-oriented environment.  The research itself was extremely enjoyable.  Mentors, as in other long-standing analysts, were great people to learn from.
cons: Disorganized leadership, which meant an uncertain future.  Some of the bosses coming through were terrible.  Some of the organizational decisions made life hard for quiet work, such as office rearrangements and moves.  The work requires quiet concentration, which was not recognized as a valid concern by higher-ups.  Also, the grants funding space was iffy at best, never knowing if your job is going to be on the chopping block or not.  Pros outweigh the cons, however.

review_title: Dream for some nightmare for others
pros: It is a highly relational campus
cons: The size of the school limits professional growth opportunities

review_title: Great Profs, Research, and Colleagues; Too Bad About the School
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Hanover, NH
pros:
There are a lot of top-notch professors at Dartmouth, and they tend not to overload themselves with advisees.
The research is good, and you're likely to get publications, conference trips, and connections.
There's a pretty good graduate student community for a social life, and good people to work with.
Grad student stipend is a bit above-average, but the cost of living in the area can be rather high as well.  Health package is p. good too.
Depends on your advisor, but in general a lot of them seem to be pretty chill with their students maintaining a reasonable work-life balance.
The area is fantastic if you like small-town life, rural/wild surroundings, and outdoor activities.
cons: The school itself is kinda messed up.  Beyond the terrible administrative bloat and inefficiency, it often seems like the school just doesn't know what it wants to be, and so it's overall slowly drifting towards mediocrity.  There's also a fairly terrible frat/social culture in the undergrad realm that seems like it's always threatening to drag down the entire school's reputation.

review_title: Small town practices evident in small minded business/employee practices
pros: Dartmouth is very supportive of having healthy employees and offered great motivators to get people working out.  Benefits are good if you work there full time and for a long time (3+ years).
cons:
No opportunity for advancement - you can just move from department to department.  There is a huge divide between the faculty and upper management who are really poor managers.  They also treat their support staff poorly and offer no recognition of quality work and no motivation to learn new skills or grow.  
Given how insular and small the community, they are not friendly to outsiders and most of the higher level managers have been there forever and are not open to new ideas.  Since they are one of the only employers in the area people have no choice but to settle for poor paying jobs and no growth.

review_title: If you love the outdoors and natural beauty Dartmouth is perfect for you!
pros:
Close to any outdoor activity you would be interested in from kayaking, hiking, biking, and the most beautiful place for a quiet run you could imagine. Everyone who works at Dartmouth seems to enjoy recreation and health. Co-workers take mindful walks or schedule walking meetings. You can also enjoy so much big city culture up close. You can take your lunch and sit in the Hood Museum with shows curated by MoMa curators or take in a show during the week of off Broadway theater or private runs of movies they release in Hanover before they ever hit national theaters.   

Professional development is at the forefront of weekly conversations, "What are you interested in? Do you want to learn more? Can you go to a conference and bring back some innovative approach."
cons: Salary growth is small and not as competitive as similar roles within industry. However Dartmouth tries to make up for what it lacks in salary through what it offers for benefits and opportunity.

review_title: Dartmouth is heaven for undergrads, a little bland for grad students, and an excellent employer
pros: Health care is excellent, grad student stipend is guaranteed for all 5 years and is higher than most graduate programs.  Small departments mean that you get to know people well, and you are forced to be interdisciplinary.
cons: Hanover has little to offer as far as entertainment. The departments are small, meaning that there is likely not more than one expert in a given field per department, which means that your networking opportunities within a field are limited.

pros: Flexible work schedule, decent pay and benefits. Most colleagues were talented and professional. Physical workspace was nice - newly designed and conveniently located in the heart of downtown Hanover.
cons:
Senior IT leadership did not have an IT education or background leading to poor decision making and several failed or delayed projects. In addition, IT priorities didn't always align with institutional goals. 

Second and third level management were arrogant and self centered. Most were more concerned about their own career and possessed limited people management skills. In two years the team had almost 100% turnover - most departing because of issues with management. 

The college operates on a consensus decision making model which can be frustrating if you're coming from the private sector. And clients (the various departments at the college) seem to have their own schedules and priorities that didn't  always align with IT leadership expectations.

review_title: Great area, wonderful people, limited institutional support
pros:
The poeple are wonderful, and the area is beautiful. Once you figure out how to navigate some of the systems in place there are opportunities for professional development and there is support to pursue that. 
health and tuition benefits are good.
cons:
There are very limited opportunities for raises and promotions. The compensation system is structured in a ridgid way that locks salaries in below industry standards. The area, while beautiful and family oriented, is not an inexpensive place to live, salaries of mid-level staff do not match the cost of living in the area. I breifly had the same job title as my husband, while I have higher level degrees than him he was paid more to do the same job...gender equality does not yet exist at Dartmouth.
While the instituiton has many resources, and is continually growing its facilities, employees are offered few "perks" for working for a large private college.

pros: The location and campus are excellent. The people I work with are also excellent. It has the quaint feel of a small New England town and there are many outdoor activities.
cons: While the location is beautiful and the township of Hanover is really nice, there can be some aspects of living here that are difficult, especially if you are not from the Northeast. Nearby Lebanon has a lot of familiar stores and shops, but the Upper Valley area can feel somewhat secluded and cut-off from shopping that is common to urban and suburban areas in other parts of the country. Airport access can be difficult at times too. Boston is just over two hours away. Manchester and Burlington are about an hour and twenty minutes away.

job_title: Information Desk Assistant in Hanover, NH
pros:
* It's a very easy, laid back job. With good shifts, there isn't too much of a bustle, and you can also choose to work with a reference librarian
* It's nice when you can help visitors and see them smile!
cons:
* People sometimes expect you to be a printer technician when really you're role is to handle questions about the library...on the other hand, you DO become amazing a fixing most printer problems since you'll be seeing a lot
* You realize how many staplers people steal in a day....

review_title: Excellent for postdoc but it's time to move on now
pros: I had a great experience doing my postdoc here. Lots of help to improve my grant writing skills and getting exposed to multiple research groups. Got promoted to faculty position after being awarded a major grant.
cons:
Being stuck in the same position and not much help from the department. Grant money is running out and the department does not want to provide bridge funding if you do not hold an R01. Many researchers and research groups have left or are leaving Dartmouth. Not a good thing if you are collaborating with them.
Benefits package not great. They moved from Anthem to Cigna, which almost does not cover anything. Very, very dissappointed in this.
I have gained from Dartmouth what it has to offer and for me it is time to leave this place.

pros: Benefits including health insurance & vacation time are definitely plus points. Administrative staff are generally polite and try to be helpful. Faculty are committed to their students & sense of school spirit among students is high.
cons: Maintaining a "harmonious" relationship with colleagues is often given preference over honest feedback and discussion about actual professional competence of employees -- the lack of which can often impede progress within campus and with the institution's external relations; Coordination across departments on projects is more challenging than expected for a relatively small academic institution.

pros:
Great pay with good benefits.
Smart coworkers who want to excel in their jobs. 
Very diverse in comparison with surrounding communities, but its understandable because its a small town. People outside of New England don't want to live in remote area with comparatively brutal long winters.
cons:
Career progression is slow because people stay with college for years due to compensation, college mission and work life balance.
Diversity in college is great. Surrounding towns are not as diverse. However, it is expected in small remote town in New England hills. I saw people who complained about diversity, but how would you attract diverse people to Dartmouth away from all the amenities and conviniences of suburbs into cold long winters? Its not that diversity isn't welcomed here. Diverse group population are not interested in moving here. Can't change it.

review_title: Dartmouth is a satisfactory place to work.
job_title: Assistant to Director in Hanover, NH
pros: Dartmouth is a prestigious place to work and has great health and education and retirement benefits. Dartmouth College is supportive of educational advancement. Dartmouth College is a pretty campus. You have access to a lot of mental stimulation. Hanover has very little crime. DHMC is close by and provides a lot of access to highly trained medical personnel. Lebanon is a wonderful small town to raise a family. West Lebanon has a lot of retail shops and restaurants and the Upper Valley is a thriving area.
cons: It is hard to advance from within at Dartmouth. They prefer to hire people from other colleges for senior positions unless the person is a graduate of Dartmouth College.

review_title: Fulfilling, but occasional challenging issues with direct management.
pros: The work of sleep disorders is interesting work. The position offered good pay. The work was often fulfilling, helping patients, and often seeing immediate improvements. The third shift schedule is helpful for some individuals. The schedule was a 3 day schedule, offering ample time off work. Coworkers were a close knit group. A great deal of autonomy was inherent in the work.
cons: The third shift was tough on time with loved ones. Some issues with management were challenging. Very close contact with patients of all types - some were difficult. Limitation of promotion to working a day shift.

review_title: Depends on the department - everything is in a silo
pros: You'll be surrounded by higher education administrators who are generally very dedicated to their jobs.
cons: It is an old institution with a very hierarchical structure.  The college administration comes third after faculty and students, and is often ignored.  Working at Dartmouth has its charm, but for me, when I was working closely with students, I became stressed out just trying to keep up with students who are stretched thin because of the high demands on their time and expectations they set for themselves.

pros: It's easy to organize research assistant work alongside classes and other things in your schedule. Dartmouth really invites you in academia. Dartmouth also creates plenty of opportunity for a student to work as a research assistant to a professor in a field they're interested in. Great experience for anyone who is considering becoming an academic!
cons: It really depends on the professor you work with. Some professors are so busy that they don't end up teaching you much about academia at all. Still, even the basic research you do will teach you something about the field.

pros: Dartmouth is an absolutely fantastic environment to work in and the Upper Valley is paradise for people that loving spending time out of doors.  My colleagues and students are incredibly bright, hard working, and interesting people.
cons: Travel out of the Upper Valley can sometimes be tricky, especially during the winter.  If you are someone that needs quick access to an international airport, then this area may not be for you.  That said, we are within easy driving distance of Boston, NYC, and Montreal.

review_title: Great spot, great people (though no health benefits, in my case!)
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Hanover, NH
pros: The area is beautiful and my postdoc (formerly PhD) adviser is a great person to work for. The Department of Physics and Astronomy is also a great place to work; most people are very friendly, and there are plenty of opportunities to get together outside work, if one is interested.
cons: My title and contract have changed twice in the past 6 months, primarily because this allows the College and my adviser to  avoid having to give me health benefits. In the scheme of it all this is a somewhat minor issue, and in my particular case (married with three kids) we very easily qualify for Medicaid on a postdoc salary.

review_title: Good for some people, not for others
pros: Beautiful scenery, well-resourced organization, name on resume opens opportunities.  People either stay here for a VERY long time, or leave after a couple years.  You don't find a lot of people in the middle.  They either love it long-term or come to dislike it quickly.
cons: Insulated, group-think, not progressive in many ways though very liberal politically.  Geographic isolation leads to ideological isolation and you sometimes get the feeling that you've stepped back in time about fifty years.

review_title: Ivy League College -- Best and the Worst
pros: 401k, Benefits, Socializing opportunities, Paid vacation, Personal leave and vacation, Friendly working environments, friendly employees, high morale,
cons: Timesheets, Poor HR Dept., Minimum of 3 Years to Keep 401k, Dis-functional Management, Poor IT Infrastructure Implementation,  Lack of Communication between DHMC and DMS, Not competitive pay, Central IT Support is poor, military structure is not working and wrong, new employee review method is terrible, rumor is central Dartmouth College doesn't or rarely employees get reviews / raises!

review_title: Working at the Athletics Facilities of Dartmouth College.
job_title: Athletics Facilities Info Desk Receptionist in Hanover, NH
pros: My work place at the Athletics Facilities has flexible times, and if there are conflicts with time slots they are always taken care for even on a short notice. Generally speaking there are lots of varying positions across numberous departments so it is relatively easy to find work that is intersting. Overall great people and good atmosphere.
cons: They could pay better (close to minimum now in many jobs) for the jobs. On the other hand many of them are simple info desk/receptionist work study positions where it is possible to do homework while at the job.

pros: It was a good place to work during college. I was a tutor at the Center for Reading, Writing and Information Technology for 2 years. My work consisted of helping students with their academic papers,  resumes, and other writing assignments, as well as advising them on new media work (such as videos, websites, and other forms of digital media).
cons: Some of the students treated wanted the tutors to essentially write their papers for them. Some students did not respect the resources available to help them learn and improve as students, but most were genuinely appreciative and willing to work hard.

job_title: Ph D Student in Hanover, NH
pros: The community is very tight knit so there is always something to do. Being in a small town means there are no distractions, which is great if you're doing research. There are always opportunities to collaborate with other researchers and Dartmouth tends to attract a lot of great ones despite its reputation as an undergraduate institution.
cons: The winters can be harsh, but if you like winter sports, this is the place to be. Skiing, snowboarding, hockey, ice skating, you name it. The Upper Valley isn't terribly diverse. Likewise, if you're a foodie, then there isn't that much to try compared to the city.

pros: The faculty here are top-notch but because the institution is primarily undergrad-oriented, they are much more available to students (and postdocs) than comparable quality faculty at larger intensively research-oriented places.  The departmental and library support staff are also incredibly helpful, for both teaching-related and research-related tasks.
cons: This is a small town, so outside of the college, there are limited cultural amenities.  Life in town is also much more expensive than in other towns of comparable size. Also, on average, the student body here is very affluent (or it feels this way): Dartmouth feels less class-diverse than some other institutions I've spent time at.

pros: Tight-knight smaller community means that you get to know the students. Elite students with a drive beyond what you experience at other colleges.  Expectations upon the employees are subject to the same
cons: There is a transient feel  due to the D-Plan where students have "off-terms" or "leave terms" at any time of the year; therefore, any programming aimed at students is arduous.  The quarter system means there are 4 quarters which are only 10 weeks long; students are constantly cramming for "mid-terms" from week 3 to the end of term.  There is no downtime, essentially, as semester schools have.

review_title: Interesting work, decent colleagues, good benefits, but inadequate pay
pros: Great, interesting work. Friendly people from a variety of backgrounds. Professional development encouraged and paid for. A chance to travel occasionally. Promotion from within. Depending on your department and supervisor, you may be able to have some flexibility in your schedule and tasks.
cons: The pay is not enough to support one person (let alone a family) in the Dartmouth College area. The cost of living is close to that of the Boston area, but the pay was slightly lower than I had been making in the Midwest in a medium-sized city.

review_title: Great place to work and live
pros: Good work environment, firendly coworkers and communicative management. On the job training was good and hours were flexible. My boss seemed genuinely interested in keeping busywork-type paperwork to a minimum. The job (undergraduate advisor, basically an RA) came with generally good housing (as far as student dorms go, that is).
cons: cold winters can be tough. Parking on campus is a pain - few spaces and a number of arcane, poorly publicized rules about who can park where. It sounds trivial until you hear that parking tickets on campus can cost as much as $50 for parking in the wrong space

job_title: Research Assistant II in Lebanon, NH
pros: Good benefits, beautiful area, lots of things to do for a small college town. If you like the outdoors and cultural experiences, you'll probably like it at Dartmouth.
cons: Working in academic research doesn't pay well as a rule, and my positions have been funded by grants, so I have basically no job security. I can't really say what it's like outside of grant-funded positions. Also, all employees were given a very stingy cost-of-living raise (less than the usual annual increase), despite the college receiving a $100 million dollar gift recently. And they justified it by saying the college was broke.

pros: Dartmouth is an excellent research-based school with a wealth of educational opportunities. You can find many entry-level positions, and the area provids you with a plenty of outdoor opportunities.
cons: As it is a private academic place, availability of positions highly depends on the availability of funding, and even if a position is available, it's not likely to continue after few months or a year or two. Obviously, HR won't share this info with you and will keep their tight lips to keep you at the lowest wage as possible as long as they can. Stay alerted.

pros: Great people, and if you love nature, this is the place to be. Basically, as a student working part-time, you can't ask for much else.
cons: You are stuck in a town without modern entertainment venues. The nearest 'city' is Boston. You are in close-quarters with your competitors 24/7 with few social options if you don't like drinking 'till you pass out in a frat basement.

pros:
well established scientists are really smart.
environment is amazing.
facilities are taken good care of.
one of the best libraries.
cons:
winters can be daunting.
place might seem boring for young people.
rental prices are high around the college, falling down rapidly with distance, along with the quality.
administration: human resources, payroll department, and some other departments are at times very ignorant, unprofessional and have too high self esteem. They consistently fail to perform their job.

pros:
- Lots of benefits, including health coverage and incentives, free tuition and workshops and counseling around the clock
- Wonderful students, that care about their education
- A lot of responsibility. Dartmouth is a small campus, so admin, assistant directors and directors have to wear multiple hats.
- Fantastic college town
cons:
- Town is rather remote. Good for a family, not for someone who is single
- As with many Ivey's Dartmouth is steeped in tradition. This makes for a lot of bureaucracy to sift through, but is something to be occasionally proud of as well.

review_title: Last few years have been difficult with administrative transitions
pros: Great mentorship and exposure to top-notch professionals in higher education. Good work-life balance and a tight-knit community. People who are passionate about education.
cons: Hanover is rural and can feel stifling for those looking for more excitement. The administrative structure seems poorly designed and keeps changing with all the administrative transitions.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Hanover, NH
pros:
Dartmouth is AWESOME. It's a great place to study and work. 

There is a lot of support for postdoctoral scholars: career advice seminars, face-to-face career coaching, internal grants, counseling, writing center, various workshops, panel discussions, round tables... All these are provided for FREE. Dartmouth cares about postdocs, we are not an "invisible nation" here.

Good health insurance + there is a health connect service, which is nearly free.
cons:
Location could be an issue for these who don't like rural areas (but I LOVE it).
Vision insurance is a joke.

pros: Great place to work. Flexible, great people, great benefits and exceptional vacation. I have been there for 7 years, have had great opportunities. They are updating the systems and it is so nice they include the people who use them to give advice on how to make things better.
cons: Systems are very complicated it takes a full year or longer to figure out the nuances.

review_title: Postdoc and young faculty go elsewhere.
pros: Upper Connecticut valley is beautiful and safe. Cheap-er than other parts of the country but not that cheap,
cons: Too much influence from Alumni, too much anti-reseach which materializes on very poor management at the Medical School. This only applies to research, can't express judgement on MD training. Poor core facilities, lousy, limited critical mass in some key areas, no long-term vision. As far as the College, decent benefits nothing else.

pros: good vacation and personal day time, nice region of the country, opportunities to meet people, decent benefits, and potential to get education for free or reduced costs.
cons: No one is ever good at getting back to you, the different dfepartmnents never talk to one another so you might have a great boss, miught have a hoirrible one.

pros:
- Dartmouth has an amazing infrastructure and I didn't have to worry about funding for my studies
- Doing a TA is not that bad, students are smart so you tend to learn from them a lot and also make good friends with them
- Situated in a small town it provides an amazing environment, don't look any further if you are a nature lover
cons:
- Not many people around, at some point you have almost seen everyone.
- Not many things to do in the area

review_title: Dartmouth College is passionate about science and this makes working there exciting and enjoyable.
pros: In the Arts and Sciences division, Dartmouth employees are very passionate about there work and that passion trickles down through all levels of the staff.
cons: While working at Dartmouth is great, life in the Upper Valley tends to get boring, it may be too rural for some.

review_title: It's academia - good and bad of all that.
job_title: Marketing Communications Manager in Hanover, NH
pros: Flexible schedule. Lots of time off for holidays.
cons: People are not friendly at Tuck School. Many love to walk by you and stick their nose in the air after you say hello. Not a lot of opportunity for advancement. You have to pay to park here ($30/month) and half the time students take your parking. You witness things you can't believe are allowed/unchecked yet staff is overly restricted.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Lebanon, NH
pros: Dartmouth is a very collaborative environment to work in. There are scientists performing all areas of research very high integrity.
cons: Lebanon is a very low-key place to work. There are not a great deal of activities in the area, so if you are a city person I would recommend looking elsewhere.

review_title: Satisfying in terms of a short term position, but not much room to grow
pros:
- Good benefits
- Exclusive resources available to the school to due its stature
- Good work/personal life balance
cons:
- Lack of a sense of community
- Lack of an established performance review system
- Due to academic environment, lack of proper management at critical levels
- Some basics needed for a commuting workforce are lacking (i.e. parking capabilities are limited and recently became 3 times more expensive than they used to)

pros: Great group of students. Interesting coworkers. Incredible work-life balance. High quality of life. Location makes it posdible to save a significant portion of income.
cons: You must be happy in cold weather & in an isolated area. Little to do outside the academic community without substantial travel.

review_title: Collaborative and engaging in such a way that taught me independence and self-sufficiency
pros: The ability to work along side with teach professors allows for the learning process to be much smoother and fluid. For entry level (0-2 years of experience) researchers, this college is highly suggested.
cons: It takes some time before you feel you are truly contributing to the overall project work of the department you are in. However, this can be significantly cut with the more research experience you have.

pros: Benefits - winter break and retirement & access to the libraries if you like that kind of stuff.
cons: It's an Ivy League institution in New England that lacks diversity. I cannot get a sense if the leadership values diversity or simply gives it lip service. Management varies significantly by department. The benefits are what keep me in this position. Seems to promote only those who have "in's" with management.

pros: Consistent pay, relaxed work environment, flexibility, nice natural environment and atmosphere, general friendliness, healthy food options, easy delivery service, promotions available
cons: sometimes menial/tedious work, surprise tasks not uncommon, sometimes requiring manual labor, sometimes no A/C in buildings, annoying college students, not always organized

pros: Benefits, work-life balance, and a small community all made the experience more pleasant than average. The location is also great: access to outdoor life.
cons: May not be recognized as a top-tier research university. Job prospects in academia are tough all-around but this may be tougher at a smaller research school.

review_title: A welcome productive environment that underperforms
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Lebanon, NH
pros: Collaborative, collegiate culture. Many resources. Excellent environment inside and out.
cons: Does not seem dedicated to advancement of current staff and does not seem committed to recruitment and retention of young active scholars in the biomedical arena. It seems a place where the good stay, and the great pass through. Currently plagued by reorganization and related budgetary woes.

pros: Friendly and smart co-workers, flexible hours (unless you are non-exempt), amazing alumni, work can be as challenging as you would like, some managers are fantastic!
cons: Technology/ reporting support needs improvement, difficult to move up/little talent management despite many motivated and hard-working people to work with, culture seemed to be shifting in a punitive direction.

review_title: Graduate student is not the best job in the world, but Dartmouth makes it feel better
pros:
Good environment, lots of support from the school, the department, and the supervisor. 
Given the fact that Dartmouth is a rather small school in the middle of nowhere, there are a lot of resources.
cons: No access to the college's child care facilities for graduate students, which can be a big problem if you are starting a family as a graduate student here.

review_title: Great place to work as student or not
pros: They are laid back. Just show up on time and no one will complain.
cons: They don't pay very well. You're better of looking for something to gain experience, not just to get cash. Not a lot of cash sitting around to pay students.

pros: Good mentor ship, reliable hours, a lot of good experience if interested in grad school. There are seminars you can attend during work hours.
cons: Not a lot of organization, a little bit of a chaotic work environment. Sometimes upper level staff are disconnected from work.

pros: Hands on work. Feel like you're making a difference in some way by helping others, while mastering a subject for your own development.
cons: You can only accomplish what the student wants to achieve in the class. With that said, it's a learning experience both ways.

review_title: There's more freedom here then in industry; but it's less organized and there's less trust in a nonacademic's abilities.
pros: Freedom to pursue various interesting research topics and to focus on designs and testing. Limited paperwork.
cons: There is a significant barrier to academics accepting an engineer's technical expertise if said engineer does not have a PhD. It can be overcome but the barrier should be diminished.

pros: Great natural surroundings, engaging students and coworkers, decent benefits. That's about all I can think of. It's easy to get bored and overwhelmed by the isolation of Hanover.
cons: Middle of nowhere, extremely cold winters, expensive location to live, far away from cities, inconvenient to travel to, and very slow-paced.

pros: The campus is really great. The people are really nice and nothing much distracting you from your work. Facilities are great.
cons: Since there is not a lot of people, you can get bored at times. Not many sources for information when you seek one.

pros: Beautiful campus nestled in the Upper Valley on the Connecticut River.
cons: I worked for a verbally abusive director for 6 months.   I asked HR for help but they were quick to say find a new job and turned the tables.   After I left,  I did some research... I was 1 of 6 employees that had left over the last 18 months (most with similar stories of the same kind of abuse).

pros:
Kind and helpful professors
Connections with local pharmaceutical companies
Great core facilities
Many opportunities to present work and conference invitations
cons:
No dental insurance
Some labs can take >6 years to graduate, different professors and departments have different standards in regards to number of publications required

pros: Wonderful institution to work for. Very friendly, helpful and highly intelligent faculty, staff and student body. Work expectations are made very clear, but with room for refinement and individual tailoring. Positions are highly sought after. Outstanding cultural enrichment with performances, exhibitions, lectures and events from local to global educators and artists.
cons: There's a reason the country's cold regions research laboratory is located in the same town; dress warmly!

job_title: Assistant Teacher in New York, NY
pros: Best paid job on campus, and it was pretty relaxed. It was a good way to meet people
cons: I had to wake up at 7:45 am, and the tone of the drill varied depending on which professor I worked for.

pros: As a research assistant I really liked the exposure I got to high level work but it is important to get a professor that you really enjoy working for. There are also a lot of resources and contacts.
cons: It's very isolated and it can be very bureaucratic at times. If you're not a US citizen there are a lot less opportunities for you.

pros: Student jobs are really well organized. Good pay and interesting jobs. It's easy to get a decent amount of hours, too!
cons: The process of finding a job is a bit complicated for students. It would be better if the various offerings were better broadcasted.

pros: I seriously cannot think of any.
cons:
* Long hours and at times they don't pay you for the hours you worked because they are cheap.
*They fire you if you become disabled at any point of your employment
*The less educated you are, the more they will respect you.
*The PAY is ABHORRANT
*They will promote someone who clearly isn't qualified simply to save money, The end result is that of having children run the business with the adults as their inferiors.
*No sense of working together as a team.
*Everyone is only out for themselves.
*Most people here are OLD.

pros: Overall, go elsewhere. If you have a great PI, things are different but lack of critical mass, great faculty and poor core facilities make good research tough and especially very slow to accomplish. Benefits below average, big cut during the 2008/09 crash, especially so health insurance.
cons: Beautiful scenery, safe, fairly affordable, great for families.

pros:
-Relaxed work atmosphere; truly a 9-5 atmosphere
-Small campus allows you to interact with many different departments
-Lots of employee perks being at a university
-Decent pay/benefits
cons:
-Hard place to be a young professional in an undergraduate-focused environment
-Rare advancement opportunities... People seem to stay in their positions at Dartmouth FOREVER
-Incredibly bureaucratic; there are 2-3 people doing what 1 capable person could do

pros: Great benefits.  Pay levels keeps community pay options competitive.
cons: The bureaucrats love their status and will protect it at all costs.  If you have initiative and/or tend to be innovative watch out, since it’s often not welcomed.

pros: Great community, great work-life-balance. Nice area to live in if you like the outdoors. Good benefits.
cons: The college has some known issues with racial tensions and gender equality. Besides, the rural location is not for everyone.

pros:
-They were willing to negotiate pay, and ultimately agreed to my salary needs
-My boss was very flexible with work/life balance (understood if child was sick, had an appt, etc.)
cons: -Parking is an absolute nightmare. Unless you want to pay 400 for a parking pass you're required to park a mile away from your building. They do offer a campus shuttle which helps.

job_title: Marketing Assistant in Randolph Center, VT

There is a variety of restaurants available in town. The Hopkins Center for the Arts and the Hood Museum are wonderful artistic resources for the campus.
cons: Parking and finding adequate housing in Hanover can be challenging.

review_title: If you want to deal with immature students
job_title: User Support Specialist in Hanover, NH
pros: well, i could work from 7 to 3 and get out in time to actually have a life.
cons: the local yocals run the joint.  the managers site in their offices with fancy cherry wood rocking chairs and oak desks eating out for lunch at the hanover inn.  the students for being "darmouth" really are not that smart.

pros: Very good experience during the study. Advisors are nice and always ready to help. Good place to live with low expenses. Lot of place for entertainment.

pros: Working at one of the leading labs in this field, I get to experience first-hand what's its like to transform science in to industry. The graduate school has many excellent programs and career opportunities.

pros: flexible hours, access to facilities in Thayer School including the machine shop and the instrument room. Good place to hang out on a warm day.

review_title: One of the most attractive all-around employers in the region.

Benefits package, specifically:

Salaries in IT very high for region.

Sluggish bureaucracy.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Hanover, NH

pros: Great and quite place for your PhD. If you like outdoor activities, there're tons of options for hiking, skiing, swimming, etc. People here are really nice. It's super safe in Hanover too.

pros: Excitement of keeping traditions alive and connecting constantly with the alumni community (tight-knit) - "lest the old traditions fail"

Emphasis on the end result, rather than the process or pathway to solution

review_title: Great place to live and work

pros: It's a pretty great environment with a lot of incredible resources, specifically in the library itself.
